Post_Title: My sexually abusive nStep-dad got arrested yesterday
post_text:
Basically, the title. He sexually abused me from the age of 10-19. I reported him to the police almost 1 year ago now, and after a lengthy investigation, he is in police custody at this moment.

I was not expecting the call from the detevtive telling me my step-father was in police custody yesterday, and all I could think when he told me was, "Oh my god. I have to tell my brother [who he physically and emotionally abused]." 

I feel like I'm finally getting some justice and closure for what happened to me. This man ruined my life, and he's gotten away with it for so long. Well, no longer. This week, the victims earned a victory.

Edit: Thank you everyone for the awards and support! I may not be able to reply to every comment, but I have read them all and I genuinely appreciate your messages of support.

To those of you who have shared your own stories, both on my post and in their own, I want you to know that you deserve all of the genuine love and affection that your abusers and nParents have denied you. You are a beautiful human being, and I hope every one of you is able to get the closure and peace that you need.

I promised to update when I found out if my nStep-father was going to be kept in police custody or released with conditions, so here's that update.

He has been released, with a laundry list of conditions. Those conditions are:

•No contact with me or [other victim who testified (hereafter OV)], directly or indirectly.

•Except as specified, no being within 200ft of me or [OV], or anywhere that we can reasonably be expected to be (home, school, work, place of worship, etc).

•No weapons (he can use tools he needs for his job when he's working and utensils needed for eating, but beyond that, he is not allowed to have anything that could be defined as a weapon in his possession).

•No contact with any child under age of 16, except with parent/guardian supervision. This includes his grandchildren.

•No seeking employment or volunteer positions that involve being in a position of power or authority over children under 16. He typically volunteers with his community theater, and he teaches young children at his church. Both of those are now completely off limits.

•No public parks or swimming areas, or anywhere that children under 16 can reasonably be expected to be present. 

Further, the police service in the area that my abuse took place is going to make a media release asking for any other victims to come forward and make statements. They hope that if more victims make statements, they can add more charges to the case against him.

As it stands, he has 6 charges against him: 3 counts of Sexual Interference under section 151 of the Criminal Code of Canada, 1 count of Sexual Exploitation under section 153 of the CCC, and 2 counts of Sexual Assault under section 173 of CCC.

I'll continue to update as court dates begin and the case goes forward.

To those of you sitting on the fence about reporting your abuse or assault, please, please report. You never know what kind of difference you can make to your life and someone else's life.

Threads.Reply_Text:
Great news! This choice to pursue justice/accountability for the abuse you experienced must have taken a lot of courage.

I hope this is part of a fruitful healing process for you, and that one day very soon you won't feel as though you have a ruined life.

Replies.Reply_Text:
Thank you so much. I genuinely appreciate that.

My hope is to see him behind bars, never in a position to hurt other girls again.

Because of him, I have struggled with maintaining normal, healthy relationships. I can't have a full-time job because of the anxiety and depression his actions directly caused.

I have been in therapy for 6 years now, and I can feel myself growing and healing in every session. I genuinely hope that getting justice will help me continue the process.

I have a case worker who has supported me through this process, and she's encouraging me to write a book after all is said and done. I think that that will help me heal as well, to put my life on paper and share it with the world.

I want to let every victim of abuse know that they are strong, and they deserve justice. They deserve to be heard. Most of all, they deserve love and everything that their abusers have denied them.

You sound like you are really on the right path, that you are taking care of yourself and doing the best you can to make some positive meaning out of this. Making the world a better place for people who also experience abuse can be a beautiful way to rewrite your own story. You and your brother are also very fortunate to have each other! Do keep us posted!

It's taken a long time to get on this right path! I'm so happy that it's coming through now.

I will absolutely keep y'all posted!

I really like your post. Thank you for posting it.

I thought I’d offer this perspective: Human pieces of shit who do things like your stepfather did/does are rare. I’m not saying they’re not real and I will say that even one of them existing is too many. But my point is that the vast majority of people aren’t like that. So I hope you’re able to find a high quality person to trust and love. And I’d say the odds are stacked heavily in your favor. Good luck to you.

Thank you very much!

I actually started dating someone about 2 months ago who seems like one of the amazing ones so far. He's the only person my cats have ever adored the way they do (seriously, one of my cats likes my bf more than the cat likes me). Considering the fact that my cats are typically excellent judges of character, I'm taking this as a good sign.
This thread has been removed because it derails the OP.

I have worked in the justice system with offenders like OP's step dad, men who move on to become scout leaders or get other positions of trust around children so they can access more kids. But that's a technicality, you clearly know better. Bygones.
This is really rude. Be kind and respectful to everyone here.

This thread has been removed. A terrible act doesn't stop being terrible just because a certain time has passed. The hurt certainly doesn't just disappear, and the OP still needs to find a way to process it.

Generally, there can be a lot of valid reasons for not reporting something immediately. Not everyone can take action right away, but that certainly doesn't mean it's unfair to do so later.
To clarify: the last act of abuse occurred when i was 19. I was 21 when I reported, and 22 now. It has not been very long since he abused me.
Even if it had been long ago, it would still have been fine. I'm sorry you experienced that abuse at all, and very happy for you now.

Thank you so much. I'm very happy that Canada removed the Statute of Limitations regarding sex crimes recently, so more victims from the past can come forward and bring their abusers and assaulters to justice.

Time passed does not matter. The trauma remains, and so does the need for closure and justice.
